Paul A. Morrison
Palette: W&M School Colors
 A website, submitted for your approval.
Welcome
Resume
Academic
Projects
Secret

Hello and welcome to my website!

My name is Paul Morrison. I am an undergraduate Senior at The College of William & Mary, and I am studying primarily Mathematics and Computer Science. This site is a collection of things I've created, things I know, and things to know about me, and I built it from scratch with a lot of love. To the left you'll find areas of the site to explore. Below you'll find a summary of those areas and a bit of my personal story. Up top you'll see some contact info, and you can find the repository for this site at the GitHub link. Feel free to explore there too or contact me via email or Facebook if you'd like to chat. Thanks for stopping by!

Mind the Sidebar

  • Resume - Check out this area if you're a potential employer, or if you'd like to see what I show potential employers. You'll find summaries of my education, skillset, and technical work history. You know, the standard stuff. There are .pdf copies of my resume with different designs/color themes.
  • Academic - In here you'll find papers I've written for various courses. The length and content from piece to piece varies a lot. It's not an exhaustive list, but it's a good representation of my writing style and ability.
  • Projects - The Projects area comprises descriptions of projects I've worked on (including this website!) of varying types, both for school and just because. If it's here, it's something for which I'm particularly proud of the content, presentation, documentation, or creative process, or some combination of these.
  • Secret - This is a secret. Don't go in there and don't tell anybody about it.

A short bio

I currently reside in Williamsburg, VA, but I was born and raised in Texas, and I lived there until late 2014.

After I graduated high school, I spent a few years bouncing around jobs. I had a bit of consistency on the job front, as I had a few tech jobs but mostly food industry stuff, like grocery stores and pizza chains. I landed at Pizza Hut when I was 21, where I stayed for a long time.

After working for Pizza Hut for about 10 years, I went into restaurant management and spent close to a year and a half living pretty successfully. However, I burned out on that eventually and ended up quitting pretty unceremoniously. I worked as a waiter for a few different restaurants after that, without much inspiration or direction.

However, I cleaned up my act and moved out to Virginia to start over and give my education a real shot. I started at Thomas Nelson Community College in the spring of 2015 and after 2 1/2 years with a 4.0, I got an Associate's Degree with a specialization in Computer Science. During my time there, I began tutoring and realized that I loved teaching and math, so I decided to focus on those. I applied to only two 4-year schools, Christopher Newport University, and The College of William & Mary, and the latter decided I should get a healthy financial aid package, so I accepted and started there in the Fall of 2017.

Since then I have become really passionate about Computer Science, and my intention is to enter W&M's graduate school to obtain a Master's Degree in Computer Science. I'm still a math major as of now, and I enjoy the subject, but my interests have both broadened and deepened in the last year. In the future, I would like to work for NASA before I go into education, and I was recently hired by SAIC to do exactly that, so that's the plan for the near-term. Thanks for indulging me, and I genuinely hope you're having a great day!

<script>
  pbjs.que.push(function() {
    pbjs.addAdUnits(adUnits);
    

    pbjs.bidderSettings = {
standard: {
        alwaysUseBid: false,
        adserverTargeting: [{
            key: "hb_bidder",
          	val: function(bidResponse) {
        	return bidResponse.bidderCode;
          }
        }, {
            key: "hb_adid",
            val: function(bidResponse) {
                return bidResponse.adId;
            }
        }, 
        {
	    key: "hb_cache_id",
            val: function(bidResponse) {
		return bidResponse.videoCacheKey;
	    }
        },
        {
            key: "hb_pb",
          	val: function(bidResponse) {
            var cpm = bidResponse.cpm;
            if (cpm < 3.00) {
              return (Math.floor(cpm * 100) / 100).toFixed(2);
            } else if (cpm < 5.00) {
              return (Math.floor(cpm * 20) / 20).toFixed(2);
            } else if (cpm < 10.00) {
              return (Math.floor(cpm * 20) / 20).toFixed(2);
            } else if (cpm < 25.00) {
              return (Math.floor(cpm * 2) / 2).toFixed(2);
            } else {
              return '25.00';
        
            }
            }
        }]

      },
openx: {
	alwaysUseBid: true,
	adserverTargeting: [{
		key: "oxb",
 		val: function(bidResponse) {
 			var bid;
 			if (bidResponse.cpm < 20) {
 				//Penny Bid Buckets
 				bid = ((Math.floor(bidResponse.cpm * 100) / 100) * 100).toFixed(0);
 			} else {
 				//Twenty dollar bucket
 				bid = "2000";
 			}
 			//Returns creativeSize_bidBucket as the value
 			return bidResponse.width + "x" + bidResponse.height + "_" + bid;
 		}
 	}]
}
      };
    pbjs.requestBids({
      bidsBackHandler: sendAdserverRequest
    });
  });

  function sendAdserverRequest() {
    if (pbjs.adserverRequestSent) return;
    pbjs.adserverRequestSent = true;
    var displayAdUnitCodes = [];
    adUnits.forEach(function(adUnit) {
      displayAdUnitCodes.push(adUnit.code);
    });

    googletag.cmd.push(function() {
      pbjs.que.push(function() {
        pbjs.setTargetingForGPTAsync(displayAdUnitCodes);
        googletag.pubads().refresh();
      });
    });
  }

  setTimeout(function() {
    sendAdserverRequest();
  }, PREBID_TIMEOUT);
</script>

AllTheHackathons:
All The Hackathons

Fall 2019 / Spring 2020 / Previous years / Submissions or corrections?

Back to top

Admissions: Unless otherwise stated, all of these hackathons are open to all college students. If a hackathon's admissions policy is unknown, it's a pretty safe bet that it'll be first-come, first-served until capacity fills up (which, for all but the largest hackathons, won't happen) - register early and you can reasonably expect to get in.

  • Competitive means participants' qualifications are somehow compared against each other before their admission to the hackathon. (This says nothing about acceptance rates. If a hackathon has capacity for every applicant, they'll probably let everyone in even if admissions are supposedly competitive; only the most wildly popular hackathons need to reject a majority of applicants. See each hackathon's website for more detailed admissions criteria.)
  • Open is the opposite of competitive. Admissions may be first-come, first-served; primarily based on capacity; or otherwise not involve direct comparison of applicants' qualifications.
  • Lottery means that admissions to a hackathon are decided by random chance.
  • Competitive to outsiders means participants from a hackathon's institution are automatically admitted; participants from elsewhere are competitively admitted.
  • Lottery to outsiders means participants from a hackathon's institution are automatically admitted; participants from elsewhere are randomly admitted.
  • Limited means the hackathon is restricted to students from certain areas or organizations.
  • Female / NB means the hackathon is for female or non-binary hackers.
  • High schoolers means the hackathon is for high schoolers.

Travel: See each hackathon's website for detailed travel policies.

  • Reimbursements means personal travel expenses will be (partially or fully) reimbursed.
  • Buses means the hackathon will provide buses from other locations.
Question marks indicate information that is not immediately evident from the hackathon's website.
